Award.AwardTitle: Advancing Audio-visual Documentation of Passamaquoddy (SIL Code PQM) Group Discourse with Archive Access via the Web as an Integrated Video and Dictionary Database

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Abstract
This project, "The Language Keepers" (NSF grant BCS-05533791, 2006-2008), addresses a central dilemma in documenting endangered languages: the decline and loss of public group discourse. The documenting of public group discourse provides linguists and Native-language teachers and students with a necessary research and learning resource. The work continues a successful Native-language documentation methodology in the Passamaquoddy communities of Maine, demonstrating the feasibility of stimulating renewed group conversation and filming natural, spontaneously spoken Passamaquoddy, especially in time-critical and culturally significant areas.

There are two components: First, the project uses the video documentation itself as feedback to participants to stimulate reflection and further discourse, creating a revived community dialogue in Passamaquoddy. Next, the existing conversational video corpus of transcribed, translated and subtitled "whole conversations," plus new conversations to be filmed, will be re-conceptualized as a non-linear, web-accessed, video database archive. This video database will be linked to the existing on-line dictionary data base. Viewers will then be able to create clusters of video and dictionary entries that contextualize the meaning of an item, conveying deeper cultural and linguistic understanding. This resource, which can be found online at www.languagekeepers.org, makes the linguistic complexity of Passamaquoddy more accessible and enables the development of innovative materials for teacher training, language learning, and research.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The project is an interdisciplinary collaboration between filmmakers, linguists, and community to address the challenges of documenting and reviving an endangered language. Passamaquoddy, an Eastern Algonquin language, has been spoken for millennia by inhabitants of Eastern Maine-New Brunswick. One of the last languages of first contact to still be spoken, Passamaquoddy represents a wealth of cultural and scientific place-based knowledge and world view. Today there are perhaps 300 fluent speakers and many who understand but do not speak. There have been no new speakers for two generations; the language is highly endangered.


The work had three related parts: 1. Using the Language Keepers method of filmmaking to convene and record natural group conversation to create an archive of videos representing life and language as it is actually lived, especially in critical (disappearing) activities; 2. Expanding the online Passamaquoddy-Maliseet Dictionary with words and phrases from the video documentation; and 3. Creating an interactive web application called the Passamaquoddy-Maliseet Language Portal (PMPortal.org) that links the video archive and the dictionary with search functions in order to advance interdisciplinary research in language, science, and culture, and support the community’s agenda for language revival.


Project accomplishments:

Documentation: Using speaker facilitators to convene and maintain conversations in the language, video feedback presentations to contextualize and deepen content, and documentary film techniques to maintain spontaneity, the project documented activities as diverse as hunting, trapping, and medicine-gathering; grief and loss from historic trauma and language loss; and stories from a recent historic land claims case. From these videos, approximately 600 new words have been added to the Portal since it was launched, bringing the database to nearly 19,000 entries. In all, 70 hours of filming were edited into 100 fully transcribed and translated video clips on the Portal. 


The Passamaquoddy Portal: Working under the guidance of project sponsor Northeast Historic Film Archive, with software developers at the University of New Brunswick-Fredericton, the first fully functional Endangered Language Portal was operationalized in fall of 2012. A complex web-based software application, the Portal links the transcribed-translated videos with the entries in the Passamaquoddy dictionary. An additional grant from the Administration for Native Americans (ANA) allowed us to develop an audio module and to record all 19,000 words and sentences with elderly speakers using portable laptop computers operated by younger trained community members. 

Users of the Passamaquoddy-Maliseet Language Portal range from native-speaking community members to linguists and other researchers, including both teachers and students of the language, in diverse settings, such as homes, schools, a prison, and elderly housing. The dictionary editors frequently receive questions via e-mail, for translations and other linguistic information.

The Portal has proven itself an ideal platform for the addition and editing of entries. Entries and edits go online immediately and can be reviewed by any user. The up-to-date contents of the dictionary can be exported in a format suitable for use in a page-maker program such as InDesign, when required for print, such as new editions of the dictionary.
